messages.message: When using the Invoice app, the "Sub_total" field and "Total_Tax" fields populated with a values that are nowhere to be found on the document. When I loaded the same document in Converse and tried to get the "total tax" it provided the proper explanation, but the math doesn't add up. This app was just promoted today with a blog post and LinkedIn promotion, yet it is providing inaccurate, inconsistent results and the inability to fix the incorrect values.

thanks for the feedback

on the math question -- GPT / LLM is known for not being able to do math well
https://www.reddit.com/r/ChatGPT/comments/11iw0l7/why_is_chat_gpt_so_incredibly_bad_in_math/ it is a language model not a math model, so asking math question often fails (even though it's able to understand the text and list out all the items to be added up, it might not perform the math / the actual addition correctly)

cc @avi for future app improvement. I'm also not very sure if the commercial invoice app should be used on a hotel receipt (sample invoices look quite different from hotel receipt) -- might be good to clarify that

This a great example of the types of basic validations we should prioritize in our apps before businesses are going to pay to use them. Many of our use cases, especially invoices, rely on math to validate that we have extracted the correct information. When we present this in an app (that we're promoting through our marketing and social channels), we should have some ability to score the confidence of the information we are returning and ensure we're not making up data and populating fields. Even if we excuse the poor math handling of Chat GPT, how do we explain populating a field with information that is nowhere to be found on the document? An error would be preferable to completely incorrect information.

In the converse app, I received three different answers when I asked it for the total tax. I recognize I used slightly different prompts, but they are all returned the wrong information -- with no indication that it is a low confidence answer.

Thanks for the feedback, @ChrisM - can you share this document with us if possible.

@Eric Han @Rafal @avi we should check if this is a case of hallucination or the app is picking up wrong values.
• `Sub_total` field of $798 seems to be sum of the three room night charges (263 + 263 + 272). 
• `Total_Tax` field seems to be calculated by subtracting this value from the total of  $936.53
